title: 110_hr6448
content: The "Caregiver Tax Relief Act of 2008" is a new law that provides a credit for taxpayers with long-term care needs. This credit is inserted after section 35 in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Caregiver Tax Relief Act of 2008" allows a credit against the tax for eligible caregivers, with an applicable credit amount of $2,500 per applicable individual. The credit is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. Adjusted gross income is defined as adjusted gross income increased by any amount excluded from gross income under specific sections. The threshold amount is $150,000 for joint returns and $75,000 for other cases. Dollar amounts are indexed for taxable years after 2009 based on medical care cost adjustments. The section discusses adjusting income thresholds for tax purposes, with specific dollar amounts and definitions for "applicable individual" based on long-term care needs certification by a physician. The term "applicable individual" is defined as someone who has at least 180 consecutive days of care, with a portion occurring within the taxable year. Certification by a physician is required within a specified period for individuals with long-term care needs. The term "applicable individual" is defined as someone who is unable to perform certain activities of daily living without assistance or supervision due to functional capacity loss or severe cognitive impairment. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, may determine that an individual aged 6 to 18 is unable to engage in age-appropriate activities if they require substantial assistance for daily living activities or supervision for protection. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, may determine that an individual aged 6 to 18, who is unable to engage in age-appropriate activities, requires supervision for protection due to severe cognitive impairment or disability. The Secretary may determine that individuals aged 6 to 18, who are unable to engage in age-appropriate activities, require supervision for protection due to severe cognitive impairment or disability. Individuals aged 2 to 6 with a loss of functional capacity in activities like eating, transferring, or mobility, or with a complex medical condition requiring management and coordination of care, may also qualify for assistance. The individual, under 2 years of age, may qualify for assistance if they require specific durable medical equipment due to a severe health condition or need a skilled practitioner for care. The individual may qualify for assistance if they have a level of disability similar to a specific condition, a complex medical condition, or 5 or more chronic conditions. The individual may qualify for assistance if they have a chronic condition lasting at least 6 months and requiring ongoing medical care. An eligible caregiver includes the taxpayer and their spouse. The taxpayer's spouse, a qualifying child, or a qualifying relative for whom the taxpayer can claim a deduction under specific sections. The individual may qualify for a standard deduction under section 63(c)(3) if they meet the requirements of clause (iv) and the residency test in lieu of the support test of section 152(d)(1)(C). The individual may qualify for a standard deduction under section 63(c)(3) if they meet the requirements of clause (iv) and the residency test in lieu of the support test of section 152(d)(1)(C). An individual can be considered an eligible caregiver if they have their principal place of abode at the taxpayer's home and meet specific criteria based on their relationship to the taxpayer or the length of time they are a member of the taxpayer's household. Special rules apply if more than one individual is an eligible caregiver for the same person. The taxpayer can be considered an eligible caregiver if each applicable individual (other than the taxpayer) files a written declaration stating they will not claim the credit. If this declaration is not filed by all individuals, the one with the highest income will be considered the eligible caregiver. Adjusted gross income shall be treated as the eligible caregiver, with specific rules for married individuals filing separately. An identification requirement is necessary for the credit to be allowed. No credit is allowed unless the taxpayer includes the name, taxpayer identification number, and physician identification number of the individual on the tax return. The credit is not allowable for a taxable year less than 12 months, except in the case of a taxpayer's death. Non-U.S. citizens or nationals are not eligible for the credit unless they are resident aliens. The tax credit is only available to resident aliens who are citizens, nationals, or resident aliens of the United States. An exception is made for adopted children who live with the taxpayer and share the same principal place of abode. The tax credit for taxpayers with long-term care needs requires the correct TIN or physician identification on the return. Tax credit for taxpayers with long-term care needs effective for taxable years after December 31, 2008.
